intro: Camelina sylvestris, commonly known as wild camelina, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes other well-known plants like mustard and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring alternate, lance-shaped leaves and small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its seeds are encased in a hard, triangular capsule, and the plant is often found in disturbed soils or along roadsides. Camelina sylvestris is also valued for its potential in biofuel production due to its high oil content.
